image.altText: Outline of a stadium as seen from Hobart's cenotaph

props.synopsis: A panel assessing the proposed Macquarie Point stadium in Hobart believes the government has grossly underestimated the cost and overestimated the benefits to such an extent that it risks Tasmania's credit rating.

title.children: Planning Commission lashes Hobart stadium plan

image.altText: Man holding sign on green lawn

props.synopsis: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese's law changes to guarantee the future of farmed salmon in Macquarie Harbour are facing counter moves, with the Bob Brown Foundation launching a legal challenge in the Federal Court.

title.children: Bob Brown Foundation launches legal challenge against PM's 'rushed' salmon bill

image.altText: The exterior of a Coles shopfront

props.synopsis: More than 20 pre-packaged salad products are being recalled by major supermarket retailers after Queensland's public health surveillance detected two products contaminated with a strain of E. coli.

title.children: Major supermarkets recall salad products due to contamination concerns

image.altText: A graphic with 15 faces with the words 'Your Say'

props.synopsis: With the federal election campaign underway, we've spoken to 15 Tasmanians from across the state's five electorates to see what topics they most want to see addressed.

title.children: Your Say: What matters to Tasmanian voters this federal election?

image.altText: Woman standing at podium delivering speech to crowd on Parliament lawns

props.synopsis: As the 30th anniversary looms for a debate that earned Tasmania a place in the world record books, three people who took part reflect on the marathon effort.

title.children: All-hours debate over 29 days snared Tasmania a world record in the 90s

image.altText: A young boy with a gold shirt and a mullet plays a silver horn instrument as an older gentleman helps him follow the score.

props.synopsis: This northern Tasmanian band will celebrate its 146th birthday but with the average player aged in their 70s, the band is looking to secure its future. It's teamed up with a local primary school, offering free tuition in the hope some of the students will gain the skills to join in.

title.children: This brass band is offering free tuition to bring in a new generation

image.altText: A woman with short hair smiles with a bull terrier resting its head on her lap in a living room with white shelving.

props.synopsis: Tasmanian state law has the weakest protections for people relying on assistance animals, and discrimination reports are growing. Those affected say considering legal action to access public spaces and necessary services is exhausting.

title.children: 'Incredibly outdated' assistance dog laws leaving people in limbo

image.altText: People in costumes perform onstage at the 13th Confucius Institute Conference in Chengdu

props.synopsis: Australia's leading universities cut ties with Confucius Institutes, but don’t cite concerns of foreign interference.

title.children: Confucius Institutes quietly disappear from six Australian universities

image.altText: A mocked-up illustration shows a train moving past a station labelled 'Airport 1'.

props.synopsis: Federal Opposition Leader Peter Dutton says a Coalition government would fund Melbourne's Airport Rail Link project and scrap federal funding for the Victorian government's Suburban Rail Loop, which he calls a "cruel hoax".

title.children: Dutton would scrap Victoria's Suburban Rail Loop, focus on airport link

image.altText: An elephant.

props.synopsis: Botswana's elephant population has doubled in recent decades, creating chaos for many who live alongside them.

title.children: One of Africa's conservation triumphs has created an unintended problem

image.altText: A woman in a blue jacket

props.synopsis: A Paris court has convicted French far-right leader Marine Le Pen of embezzling money from the European parliament.

title.children: French far-right leader found guilty of embezzling EU funds

image.altText: the US and China flags both hang separately but next to each other

props.synopsis: The six individuals targeted by the sanctions include Hong Kong's police chief and a senior justice secretary.

title.children: US sanctions Chinese and Hong Kong officials over rights abuses

image.altText: Man in jacket and broad-brimmed hat in doorway with floodwaters

props.synopsis: Ferocious floodwaters in outback Queensland have not only taken homes, but entire livelihoods.

title.children: Amid the stench of dead animals, the water came 'quick and destructive'

image.altText: Excavators and diggers working in a large peat bog in the middle of a European forest.

props.synopsis: Authorities are still searching for a fourth soldier, after the armoured vehicle they were travelling in went missing while participating in a military drill.

title.children: Bodies of three US soldiers found after vehicle sank in Lithuania swamp

image.altText: Tony Mokbel being lead into court from a prison van by an officer

props.synopsis: Tony Mokbel is seeking to be released on bail after serving nearly two decades in prison for drug trafficking.

title.children: Tony Mokbel seeks bail amid appeal against drug trafficking convictions

image.altText: A still from CCTV footage shows three security guards (faces blurred) surrounding a man on the ground

props.synopsis: Footage emerges of three government-funded security guards kicking and stomping on a man on a Darwin street.

title.children: James's night out ended with a boot to the head from NT's 'quasi police'

image.altText: Gout Gout crouches after 200m at Maurie Plant Meet.

props.synopsis: Gout Gout has begun to transcend the sport of athletics in Australia, but his surprising loss at the weekend served as a reminder that he's still a teenager and ultimately success is never guaranteed.

title.children: 'He's quite angry': Gout Gout's coach speaks out on his loss

image.altText: Seven workers in high-viz clothing controls a person on a stretcher who is being hoisted down from a ruined building

props.synopsis: More than three days since the massive earthquake that rocked the region, rescuers are finding survivors under the rubble but time is fast running out to save others who haven't been found.

title.children: More than 2,000 killed by Myanmar quake, desperate rescue efforts continue

image.altText: A Flinders University sign on a glass wall.

props.synopsis: Federal Labor pledges to contribute $150 million towards a new $300 million healthcare centre planned at Flinders University, if re-elected in May.

title.children: Labor announces $150 million for health training hub in SA

image.altText: A sticker on a product saying Australia made with a kangaroo symbol

props.synopsis: Australians are being encouraged to swap American goods for home-grown products at the check-out, but is it that easy?

title.children: 'Buy local' sounds like sensible anti-trade war strategy. But how realistic is it?

props.synopsis: Australians struggling in work and on welfare have challenged campaigning politicians to do more to help. Labor and Liberal frontbenchers insisted their focus was on cost of living.

title.children: 'How can I survive?': Politicians confronted by voters doing it tough on Q+A

image.altText: A person with manicured nails holding a RAT test

props.synopsis: In recent years, the familiar symptoms of the flu might kick us into reaching for at-home testing kits. But on the eve of the next flu season, public health experts say the best approach is what we've always done.

title.children: Is it worth taking a RAT when you have a cold to find out what it is?

image.altText: Crocodile on a green background.

props.synopsis: The Department of the Environment says it is likely that a small freshwater crocodile found on a suburban Gold Coast street is an escaped pet or has been taken illegally from the wild.

title.children: Crocodile found on Gold Coast street may be escaped pet

image.altText: a forensic officers in a white hazmat suit inspects a house while holding a camera after a mother stabbed her three children

props.synopsis: The mother and three children were found with multiple stab wounds at a home in Baulkham Hills. They remain in hospital in a stable condition.

title.children: Mother charged with attempted murder of three children in Sydney

image.altText: Adam Watt portrait photo

props.synopsis: Inside the jail courtyard Adam felt out of place. He had just signed a media deal and was looking forward to stepping into the limelight until it all came crashing down. At the top of his list is one man, a corrupt cop charged with drug offences.

title.children: In prison and out of his depth, one man started investigating a corrupt cop

image.altText: Ben Cannon wears a shirt that reads 'voice for victims' while speaking into a megaphone

props.synopsis: Voices for Victims has the ear of the LNP government in Queensland, consulting the premier on the state's youth justice law changes — but the group remains adamant it has no political affiliations.

title.children: In Queensland, the influence of a victims of crime group is growing

image.altText: A flooded town with homes and roofs poking out from brown water.

props.synopsis: Residents in the tiny town of Thargomindah in south-west Queensland move to higher ground, as they brace for the full impact of floodwaters from upstream.

title.children: South-west Qld town fighting 'losing battle' against rising floodwater

image.altText: Adam Doueihi running with the ball under his arm, breaking through a tackle

props.synopsis: Wests Tigers face the biggest test of their season on Saturday, but the match-up against Brisbane could be personal for the Broncos coach Michael Maguire, according to injured Tiger Adam Doueihi.

title.children: Doueihi says Tigers clash likely to be personal for Brisbane coach

image.altText: GettyImages-2207446962

props.synopsis: The sea shanty Bound for South Australia has become an anthem that celebrates the distinctiveness of a state not necessarily renowned for distinction, especially on the sporting field. But the song captures the sentiment of the state's remarkable Sheffield Shield win, writes Daniel Keane.

title.children: The Sheffield Shield was Bound for South Australia, now it has arrived

image.altText: The Tan Suo Yi Hao in the ocean.

props.synopsis: Maritime tracking websites have recorded the Tan Suo Yi Hao — a high-tech Chinese research vessel — passing the Victorian coastline in recent days, after it completed joint surveys with New Zealand.

title.children: 'I would prefer that it wasn't there': PM says Australia monitoring Chinese ship

image.altText: A woman with long blonde hair sits in an armchair and looks over her right shoulder at a window.

props.synopsis: Australia's corporate watchdog calls on superannuation funds to overhaul the way they deal with death insurance claims, noting excessive delays, poor customer service and ineffective claims handling.

title.children: Cathy was compensated just $29 for super fund's death benefit delay

image.altText: organic green vegetables, sugar cubes, marshmallow, pills and blood sugar test set on blue background

props.synopsis: A total 6.6 per cent of Australians over the age of 18 have diabetes — an increase of 1.5 per cent when compared to a decade ago.

title.children: One in 15 Australian adults living with diabetes in 'growing epidemic'

image.altText: A yellow ant.

props.synopsis: Scientists say land managers in Queensland's Wet Tropics are winning the war against one of the world's worst invasive ant species but fear the gains could be lost if federal funding is allowed to run out.

title.children: One of Australia's most successful pest eradication programs hangs in balance
